answers.answer: HiThanks for writing to the forum!“Hallucinations are a symptom of either a medical (e.g., epilepsy), neurological, or mental disorder. Hallucinations may be present in any of the following mental disorders: psychotic disorders (including schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, schizophreniform disorder, shared psychotic disorder, brief psychotic disorder, substance-induced psychotic disorder), bipolar disorder, major depression with psychotic features, delirium, or dementia. Auditory hallucinations, in particular, are common in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.” Refer: http://www.minddisorders.com/Flu-Inv/Hallucinations.htmlDepression, dementia, alcohol abuse, migraines, diabetes, abuse of certain drugs etc can also cause auditory hallucinations.It is difficult to diagnose and treat this without professional help. A comprehensive investigation is required keeping all the points in mind.It is difficult to comment beyond this at this stage.  Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

question: My 61 year old aunt called my sister yesterday to tell her that our mother had her son (my sister's) and was going to take her to court for custody.  She also has told her in the past month that she hears a symphony constantly playing.  I did some online research and came up with auditory hallucinations?  My aunt has lived alone for the majority of her adult life and lost her house that she bought and had paid off last summer to the big flood in Cedar Rapids, IA -when this hearing of music began.  My mom is worried that she may have some more serious physical/mental problem that is causing this but has mentioned it to another family member who thinks its not a big deal.  The likelyhood of my aunt going to a doctor to check this out is slim and she has no insurance.  How do we approach this?
title: Aunt suffering from Auditory hallucinations
